publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-3399# Brian Fitzpatrick: Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black-That the Parliament recognises the lifelong commitment of Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black to the medical profession, the cause of social justice and the campaign to reduce health inequalities across the United Kingdom and the rest of the world; pays tribute to his contribution to the National Health Service as a physician, scientist, professor of medicine, President of the Royal College of Physicians and President of the British Medical Association and also as a steadfast campaigner for recognition of the links between poverty and ill-health, most notably in his scholarship and research in the pioneering work comprised in the report, Inequalities in Health, which provided evidence that at every important stage of life people of the lowest incomes suffered disproportionately from ill-health and premature death; extends its thanks for his work to build a better future, and extends its deepest sympathy and condolences to Sir Douglas' wife, children, family and many friends on his death on 13th September 2002.
S1M-3399# Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black (lodged on 17 September 2002) Ms Wendy Alexander*, Rhoda Grant*, Margaret Jamieson*, Cathie Craigie*, Helen Eadie*, Mr Kenneth Macintosh*

S1M-3399# Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black (lodged on 17 September 2002) Mr Michael McMahon*, Rhona Brankin*, Johann Lamont*, Karen Gillon*, Maureen Macmillan*, Mr John McAllion*, Scott Barrie*, Des McNulty*, Tommy Sheridan*

S1M-3399# Brian Fitzpatrick: Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black-That the Parliament recognises the lifelong commitment of Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black to the medical profession, the cause of social justice and the campaign to reduce health inequalities across the United Kingdom and the rest of the world; pays tribute to his contribution to the National Health Service as a physician, scientist, professor of medicine, President of the Royal College of Physicians and President of the British Medical Association and also as a steadfast campaigner for recognition of the links between poverty and ill-health, most notably in his scholarship and research in the pioneering work comprised in the report, Inequalities in Health, which provided evidence that at every important stage of life people of the lowest incomes suffered disproportionately from ill-health and premature death; extends its thanks for his work to build a better future, and extends its deepest sympathy and condolences to Sir Douglas' wife, children, family and many friends on his death on 13th September 2002. Supported by: Ms Wendy Alexander, Rhoda Grant, Margaret Jamieson, Cathie Craigie, Helen Eadie, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Mr Michael McMahon, Rhona Brankin, Johann Lamont, Karen Gillon, Maureen Macmillan, Mr John McAllion, Scott Barrie, Des McNulty, Tommy Sheridan
S1M-3399# Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black (lodged on 17 September 2002) Elaine Thomson*, Susan Deacon*
S1M-3399# Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black (lodged on 17 September 2002) Cathy Peattie*, Marilyn Livingstone*
S1M-3399# Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black (lodged on 17 September 2002) Donald Gorrie*
S1M-3399# Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black (lodged on 17 September 2002) Angus MacKay*
S1M-3399# Douglas Andrew Kilgour Black (lodged on 17 September 2002) Mr Kenneth Gibson*
